item.title: Risk Assessment: weETH Collateral on Sparklend Mainnet
item.dc:creator: monet-supply
item.description:
Disclaimer: The data and information presented here is provided for informational purposes only, on an “as is” basis, and without warranty of any kind. This is not intended or offered as financial, legal, regulatory, tax, or investment advice. References to any digital assets or protocols are for informational purposes only and are not a recommendation or solicitation to engage with any asset or protocol. Any projections, estimates, forecasts, targets, prospects, and/or opinions expressed in these materials are subject to change without notice and may differ or be contrary to opinions expressed by others. MKR voters and MakerDAO governance retain full control over parameter changes and are free to use or disregard this information as they see fit.

Assessment Summary

  • BA Labs supports listing weETH token on Sparklend mainnet deployment
  • Reference parameters for weETH are listed below

Overview

Sparklend is a fork of the Aave v3 protocol. In addition to the standard features of Aave v3, Spark has a close integration with the core Maker protocol to facilitate deep liquidity and low, stable DAI borrowing rates.

To date, the Sparklend mainnet deployment has restricted listings to a very limited number of assets including the largest and most lindy liquid staking tokens, which keeps the overall risk exposure of the market low. However, with the recent growth of restaking activity in defi, there is now a growing opportunity to take advantage of unmet borrowing demand by listing liquid restaking tokens (LRTs).

Etherfi’s weETH is the largest and most liquid LRT on the market currently, with over $4 billion in TVL. Etherfi also stands out as the only large LRT with withdrawals fully enabled, which helps ensure stable liquidity and a strong peg vs underlying ETH. Given these features, and current low level of competition for borrowing USD stablecoins using LRT collateral, listing weETH offers an attractive growth opportunity to increase total DAI borrow volume on Sparklend.

Fundamental Risk

This section covers fundamental and qualitative risk factors for Etherfi, Eigenlayer, and weETH.

Technical Risk

Both Etherfi and Eigenlayer have gone through significant auditing and code review processes. Eigenlayer has undergone 4 audits plus an audit competition, while Etherfi has also undergone 4 audits plus an audit competition. Eigenlayer and Etherfi also offer bug bounty programs through Immunefi, with maximum payouts of $2 million and $200,000 respectively. While the auditing and bounty provisions are adequate, the maximum caps for bounties may be on the low end considering the amount of value secured in the protocols. In each case, the maximum bounty payout is well below 0.01% of the protocols’ TVL.

Etherfi and Eigenlayer have both been operating without exploits or bugs for roughly 1 year. Given the significant time integrated TVL during this period, they have accrued a decent level of technical lindyness. However, each protocol has seen upgrades over this period particularly to support AVS, which opens up the possibility of bugs being introduced into the protocols. So we can only rely on historical time and TVL as evidence of security to a limited degree.

Validation and Slashing Risk

As a liquid restaking token, weETH is subject to validation risk and slashing conditions for not only Ethereum protocol staking, but also staking via Eigenlayer AVS. Currently, Eigenlayer does not have slashing enabled for AVS staking, so there is no direct threat of slashing from operator failures during restaking. AVS slashing is not expected to be enabled in the near future, but over the medium term this will present an additional operational risk to LRTs like weETH.

Etherfi currently has a whitelisting process to accept operators to validate for the protocol. Once whitelisted by the team (based on the team’s assessment of operator performance history and infrastructure), operators can place bids in ETH to earn the right to operate an Etherfi validator. There are plans to open up validation to more operators over time but the exact details to remove whitelisting have not been shared at present. As Etherfi onboards with more AVS, the operational overhead for validating for weETH is expected to increase significantly, and operator management may present a key challenge for scaling the protocol and minimizing slashing risk.

Etherfi has also entered into certain restaking agreements with AVS which commit them to providing certain amounts of restaked value (eg. Ethos). This may help boost weETH returns, but also represents a significant commitment on the part of token holders due to restaking operational risks and lack of clarity over returns. If Etherfi is unable to provide the agreed upon restake amount, weETH holders may also lose the potential benefits of AVS rewards or token distributions.

Centralization and Admin Risk

Etherfi recently launched their governance token ETHFI via an airdrop to stakers. However, at present key admin authorities over the protocol are controlled by a 4 of 7 multisig, with 3 signers from the core team and 4 external signers. Most controls sit behind a 3 day timelock, with the exception of AVS related actions which are not subject to timelock due to their active state of development and deployment. The timeline for renouncing centralized admin authorities or transferring them to the DAO is somewhat unclear, with a stated plan to deploy full DAO governance in the coming months. The ETHFI governance token is immutable and has a fixed supply.

Redemptions

Etherfi stands out as the only large LRT to offer redemptions to ETH. This provides a key arbitrage mechanism in cases where weETH falls below the value of underlying ETH holdings, as users can buy up discounted weETH and then unstake. This is similar to other LSTs like stETH and rETH, where activation of redemptions has significantly improved their resilience and peg strength. As an example, stETH saw persistent discounts vs peg of up to 7% before redemptions were enabled, but since then the stETH price has consistently stayed within 0.5% of underlying value.

Coingecko stETH

Eigenlayer introduces an additional 1 week withdrawal delay for restaked ETH, so we can expect that redemptions may provide somewhat lower price support for weETH versus traditional LSTs. Because of the additional Eigenlayer withdrawal delay, we estimate that fully withdrawing from weETH will take roughly 1 week longer than withdrawing from comparable LSTs like rETH or stETH. The result is that LRTs like weETH are likely to face larger discounts in a broad based market crash vs traditional LSTs like rETH and stETH, as the redemption arbitrage loop has a greater duration and therefore a lower yield to maturity for a given discount.

EtherFi also maintains a pool of liquid ETH inside the protocol to service withdrawals within 24 hours of user requests. Historically, this has amounted to roughly 2-3% of total ETH backing, and currently it is somewhat higher at roughly ~120,000 ETH. This represents an additional source of available liquidity to service withdrawals immediately, which can help prevent weETH from trading below redemption value during a market crash.

Market Risk and Liquidity

This section discusses market and liquidity risk factors and process for determining appropriate asset specific parameters.

weETH Liquidity Profile

weETH has several onchain sources of liquidity via DEX pools, in addition to the primary market liquidity provided through minting and redemptions. The largest DEX for weETH on mainnet is Uniswap v3, with $84 million TVL in weETH<>ETH pool and $29 million TVL in weETH<>wstETH pool. Balancer also offers an additional liquidity source, with $46 million in a weETH<>rETH pool and $15 million in a LRT pool including weETH, Renzo’s ezETH, and Swell’s rswETH.

However, the selection of pair assets makes some of these pools less resilient in case of broad market downturns or buildups in the Ethereum staking withdrawal queue. For example, the LRT Balancer pool provides limited assurance as neither ezETH or rswETH are currently redeemable, so any weETH sold through this pool would need to rely on limited secondary market liquidity for these tokens to swap into ETH or stablecoins. If a withdrawal queue builds up, then this could lead to broad based depegs across LSTs like wstETH and rETH, which would also drag down weETH price and make the weETH<>LST pools less useful.

The Uniswap weETH<>ETH pool is arguably the most resilient and useful of the liquidity pools as it doesn’t have any reliance on other LSTs/LRTs. However, we note that there is only roughly 20,000 worth of ETH held in the pool available to buy weETH below peg, and it is highly concentrated within ~0.5% of current price. The weETH<>wstETH pool is similarly concentrated, with all wstETH buy side liquidity within 0.2% of current price.

Uniswap Info (v3 weETH<>ETH 0.05%)

Taking aggregated liquidity across all sources from Cowswap, we see that sales up to around ~40,000 weETH can be executed with low market impact, but beyond this point liquidity drops off precipitously. Also note that because liquidity is highly concentrated around redemption price and relies partly on pairs with other LSTs/LRTs, we can expect the market depth to be much lower in cases where weETH trades below par or if there is broad based stress across staked ETH tokens.

The biggest source of off-peg liquidity (eg. 1-10% away from redemption rate of weETH) is on Balancer, which holds significant liquidity in a composable stable pool, a pool type which provides concentrated liquidity but continues to provide at least some liquidity over the entire range of possible prices. We see the primary Balancer pool with rETH offers liquidity to sell roughly ~3,600 weETH with up to 1% price discount, ~500 additional weETH to reach 2% discount, ~250 to reach 3% discount, and only another ~650 weETH sold to reach all the way to 10% divergence from peg. This demonstrates just how thin liquidity gets below peg, even in the largest pool that provides for full range weETH liquidity on mainnet.

Data: weETH on Sparklend Mainnet

There are fairly significant pools of onchain leverage using weETH as collateral, which could potentially represent a demand on liquidity in a depeg event. Morpho has ~$15 million of ETH borrowed against weETH at up to 86% LTV, using live oracle pricing through Redstone. Aave has ~$595 million of ETH borrowed against weETH at up to 95% LTV (along with very small amounts of stablecoins collateralized by weETH), but in this case uses fixed pricing where eETH is assumed to always equal 1 ETH, which may lower the risk of sudden cascading liquidations. However, Aave users would still face some liquidation risk, as LST and LRT depegs would tend to push up the utilization and borrow rate for Aave ETH above rate of return for staking, which could push positions into liquidation over time via negative net interest accruals.

To summarize, DEX liquidity for weETH is ample in normal conditions but may become exhausted during market crashes. The most important source of liquidity for weETH remains the primary market redemptions process. Deeper liquidity over a wider range below peg would help increase efficiency of the redemption arbitrage process during depegs, and provide additional assurance against disorderly flash crashes.

Oracle Settings and Price Deviation Risk

weETH can be priced using live market pricing via oracle, or via exchange rate pricing as measured by the weETH to eETH ratio in the wrapping, considering eETH to be worth a fixed 1 ETH value based on redeemability. Aave currently uses an exchange rate pricing mechanism for weETH on their deployment, while Morpho uses live pricing.

Live pricing has the advantage of potentially liquidation positions earlier in a depeg, before the price of weETH potentially falls further, and can also better account for the possibility of permanent impairments due to technical or slashing losses. But on the other hand, this also creates additional risk of liquidating at excessively low prices during a flash crash, as liquidations and oracle updates can lead to a negative feedback loop of lower prices creating more selling pressure creating further price drops. This sort of event was recently seen on Renzo’s ezETH, which crashed to below 0.8 ETH before quickly recovering.

On balance, we believe using an exchange rate pricing mechanism rather than live oracle pricing is more appropriate for weETH. While the availability of redemptions may help reduce depeg risk, there is still a possibility of flash crashes occurring as it can take some time for bidders to step in to purchase weETH below par and arbitrage redemptions, while liquidations can happen immediately. Using exchange rate pricing eliminates the risk of liquidating positions based on short term price wicks, which can negatively impact UX and may even result in bad debt to the protocol depending on how low the price falls temporarily.

However, using exchange rate pricing does create a few new risks. weETH trading at a discount to the exchange/redemption rate results in a higher effective liquidation threshold, as the fair market value of collateral will be lower than suggested by the protocol. And if the weETH discount is larger than the liquidation penalty for weETH collateral, this would halt the liquidation process as liquidating unsafe positions would no longer be profitable (the value of debt repaid would be greater than immediately achievable value of collateral received). weETH parameters such as liquidation threshold (LT), maximum loan to value ratio (LTV), and liquidation penalty should be set with this in mind to account for any reasonably foreseeable, persistent weETH price discounts.

Our primary mode of evaluating maximum potential discount is by assessing arbitrage profitability from purchasing and redeeming discounted weETH. We make aggressive assumptions that 30% of staked ETH collateral on Aave, Maker, and Compound result in net withdrawals, and 10% of remaining staked ETH is withdrawn, resulting in roughly ~40 days to fully clear the staking withdrawal queue. Then, we compare LST withdrawals vs LRTs like weETH, based on the assumptions that the Eigenlayer withdrawal period puts LRTs towards the end of the exit queue and that arbitrageurs will demand more excess return to unstake LRTs versus traditional LSTs. The resulting estimates are shared below.

LST Liquidity Risk

We estimate that LRTs like weETH may experience mid single digit percent discounts based on these arbitrage assumptions, versus low single digit discounts for LSTs like stETH. This suggests that liquidation penalty and liquidation threshold should be set more conservatively for weETH vs Spark’s LST markets.

weETH Parameters

The following parameters are proposed based on current market and liquidity conditions for weETH. We recommend to list weETH in isolation mode to prevent it from being used to borrow ETH on equal terms with stETH and rETH, which have a materially lower fundamental and liquidity risk profile. Current omnipool lending protocols like Sparklend cannot charge differential borrowing rates depending on collateral used, so allowing weETH to borrow ETH may not lead to increased ETH supply yield or protocol revenue until substantially all wstETH and rETH collateralized ETH borrowers have been displaced from the protocol. Until this threshold is reached, allowing this would result in increased protocol and liquidity risk with all value being leaked to consumer surplus of weETH collateral users.

Isolation mode will allow weETH to only be used to borrow DAI, where the risk premia versus alternative collaterals can be equalized through the use of more conservative LTV and liquidation threshold parameters. Due to the significant impact of points earned on weETH, we recommend to disable borrowing as any supply yield earned would likely be less valuable than Etherfi and Eigenlayer points.

Isolated debt ceiling is set to limit tail risk from unutilized borrowing capacity, with the debt ceiling roughly equaling Maker’s surplus buffer. However, if weETH collateral shows strong demand with the limit being utilized fully, the debt ceiling and supply cap max parameters can be progressively increased. Liquidation threshold is also set conservatively to account for potential price divergence, accommodating up to roughly 8% additional discount vs wstETH. Better liquidity depth below peg or demonstrated peg resilience during a broad based market crash would support raising LT and LTV closer towards parity with Spark’s wstETH and rETH parameters.

item.title: Fintegrate Rate Engine (FiRE): Introduction, assessment, and request for feedback
item.dc:creator: DeFlamiingo
item.description:
Abstract

This post aims to introduce a new Interest Rate Model for Maker, the Fintegrate Rate Engine (FiRE). Its goal is generating optimal Base Rates which depend on the real economy, centralized exchanges, and Maker’s collateral dynamics. The way this model will be implemented makes it possible to change the suggested parameters at any time. The final goal of the model is the automation of Stability Fees through an oracle-based implementation.

In short, the FiRE generates the Base Rate using a Low-Risk Rate (the 3M T-bills) at 0% Crypto Exposure (percentage of DAI backed by crypto collateral) which increases until Target Crypto Exposure, where it will be equal to the Benchmark Rate (the funding rates on CEXs), scaled by a multiplier. After the Target Crypto Exposure, the rate increases at a larger rate, to reach a maximum (in this case 50%) at 100% Crypto Exposure. The final output of the model will be the Base Rate, which will then be used to calculate Stability Fees and various borrowing rates across AllocatorDAOs as part of the Endgame.

The resulting stability fees will be the generated Base Rate plus spreads for different Liquidation Ratios and Vault Types or other future factors depending on the activity of AllocatorDAOs.

Since we believe this would be an innovative approach to stability fee calculation, we are requesting the community’s feedback to comment, criticize, praise, or question this model, in order to improve it and make it a unique example in the DeFi landscape. This would put the protocol in the position of rate “maker” and not rate “taker”.

We are requesting the community’s feedback over the following points:

  1. Choice of the implemented input parameters, namely:
  • the 3m T-bills as the Low-Risk Rate
  • 50% BTC and 50% ETH Average of Daily Annualized Funding Rates on Binance as the Benchmark Rate
  • the percentage of DAI backed by crypto collateral as the Crypto Exposure
  1. Choice of the smoothing technique used to stabilize the generated Base Rates.
  2. Choice of the Minimum and Maximum Rate used to bound Base Rate spikes.
  3. Choice of the implementation of the Base Rate into Stability Fees calculation.
  4. Anything else related to the model itself.

The following post addresses different aspects of the model that you can explore in detail.

Introduction and rationale

Maker has always been the reference point for DeFi rates. As an example, AAVE has adjusted GHO’s borrow rate and the Slope parameters of its markets based on the changes in DSR (Proposal 1, Proposal 2, Proposal 3…). Exposure to crypto collateral is a very important parameter for Maker, since it can affect peg stability and profit estimation, by affecting the average yield that could be earned by the protocol.

Over the past year, Maker’s approach to stability fees can be categorized into three phases:

  • Adjustment of the Stability Collateral Yield Benchmark and Yield Collateral Yield Benchmark
  • Adjustment based on the Exposure Model
  • Adjustment based on external rate environment

The first approach was unsuccessful because it relied solely on the Yield Collateral Yield Benchmark and the Stability Collateral Yield Benchmark, ignoring the potential external rates achievable in crypto markets. This oversight could result in DAI losing its peg. The second approach, while more accurate, failed to react promptly to sudden changes. The third approach, which successfully priced in borrow rates, presents a philosophical challenge for the Maker protocol and cannot be automated.

In the DeFi ecosystem, this protocol is viewed as the rate “maker”, setting a standard that others should follow for rate expectations as the largest source of liquidity. However, the latest approach positions the protocol, to a certain extent, as a rate “taker”.

Consequently, BA Labs is proposing a new framework for stability fee calculation that would position the protocol as a leader in DeFi rate management and in general be more reactive to the external rate environment. This framework would be responsive to developments in the real economy, centralized exchanges, and Maker itself. We suggest naming this framework the Fintegrate Rate Engine (FiRE), as it integrates various financial dimensions with the goal of becoming an automated, oracle-based model during the Endgame Initiative.

FiRE - The new Interest Rate Model

Language Definition

The parameters used to define the model will be the following:

  • Target Crypto Exposure (TCE): this is the target exposure to crypto collateral in the MakerDAO protocol.

  • Minimum Rate (MinR): the minimum rate set by the governance for any given interest rate environment.

  • Maximum Rate (MaxR): the maximum rate set by the governance for any given interest rate environment.

  • Low-Risk Rate (LR): the starting rate for any given exposure level.

  • Benchmark Rate (BR): the optimal rate at target exposure.

  • Crypto Exposure (CE): the current amount of DAI backed by crypto collateral in percentage terms.

  • Multiplier (m): a number used to affect the impact of the benchmark rate.

Background

In 2021, MakerDAO allocated funds to a credit pool managed by Harbor Trade Credit (“HTC”). HTC utilized these and other funds to extend $2.1 million in loans to a consumer electronics company named Snakebyte. As of writing, the $2.1 million in loans to Snakebyte is the sole asset in the HTC pool, which serves as collateral for MakerDAO’s $1.6 million senior position.

In April 2023, Snakebyte defaulted on its loan, prompting HTC to pursue legal action and successfully obtain a default judgment from the Superior Court of California - County of San Diego (the “Court”) against Snakebyte USA, Inc. This judgment empowered HTC to seize assets through a writ of attachment.

Efforts to locate Snakebyte’s assets within the United States have proven challenging. However, legal counsel has advised that Snakebyte holds material assets in Germany. Consequently, HTC now seeks to enforce the California judgment in Germany, and requests a financial contribution from the DAO to cover the associated legal costs.

The DAO Resolution below authorizes the allocation of $194,000 from the Launch Budget towards the HTC-Snakebyte litigation.

DAO Resolution to Allocate Funds to HTC Legal Action Against Snakebyte

Description Amount

Total owed to Maker $1.6 million
US legal costs estimate $73,000
German legal costs estimate $121,000

Note: The estimated legal costs were arrived at by consulting with both California and German counsel. If the case is settled early or the process is completed much earlier than expected, ultimate legal costs may be lower. In such an event, any amounts set aside for the case would be returned to the DAO.

As part of this arrangement, Steakhouse will be responsible for: (i) monitoring the progress of the litigation; (ii) reporting to the DAO; (iii) overseeing the disbursement of funds to counsel; and (iv) monitoring the disbursement of any recovered assets to the DAO.

item.description:
Given that AVCs will be disable after MIP102c2-SP29 passes on 27 May 2024 1600UTC we have prepared and finalized a position document for this quarter ahead of the end of Q2.

Please find it below:

KISS AVC - Position Document Proposal (Q2 2024)

This document has two parts:

  1. A general overview of the KISS AVC principles and viewpoints, acting as the KISS AVC Aligned Governance Strategy Position Document.
  2. Five (5) specific position statements on each of the five (5) Scope Artifacts. Each section first focuses on the Scope Improvement Articles. Some Scope sections cover topics outside of Scope Improvement Articles at the end of each respective Scope section. Whenever we propose new tasks (“Advisory Works”) for Advisory Councils, we added our perceived priority, from low (Priority 1/5) to high (Priority 5/5).

Remark: In this document we often refer to Advisory Council members as Scope Advisors. The two terms are interchangeable.

KISS AVC - Aligned Governance Strategy

The KISS AVC is hawkish primarily because it wants spending to be extremely focused and purposeful. It believes DAI should remain stable, decentralized and uncensorable. Also that MKR holders should be rewarded. While we embrace complexity, our mantra is “Keep it simple, stupid!”

The KISS AVC identifies the following two fundamental goals.

G1) DAI, the decentralized stablecoin, is the product of MakerDAO and its main focus. It must remain stable, decentralized, open to everybody and uncensorable.

G2) People with stake in the game are DAI holders and MKR holders. DAI holders rely on the key characteristics of DAI listed above. MKR holders have invested their own money in the project and must to be rewarded. The reward must be primarily financial but can also come in other forms: sense of stability and trust in the protocol, status, fulfillment, etc.

The KISS AVC wants to achieve the above two goals by:

A) Embrace complexity.
The two goals above are extremely ambitious and require sophisticated and complex solutions. MakerDAO needs to attract and keep the best talents in order to succeed.

B) Strive for simplicity. But avoid “simplistic” solutions to complex problems.

Attributed to Leonardo Da Vinci: “Simplicity is the ultimate sophistication”.

Attributed to Albert Einstein: “Make everything as simple as possible, but not simpler”.

C) Keep it simple stupid! (KISS)
Simplicity, once established, must actively be “kept” intact. It is of paramount importance to keep the focus on the two main goals (G1 and G2) and to avoid potentially harmful complexity explosions.

Section MIP 104 (Stability Scope)

Scope Advisors should work in tight coordination with Facilitators and Arrangers based on actual data. Facilitators should disclose information as needed, while respecting confidentiality requirements.

The Stability Scope largely requires expertise to edit it. We have a Scope Advisor for it which has already been suggesting edits to parameters within the scope constantly and doing a good job of managing the scope

Section MIP 106 (Support Scope)

Advisory Work for Support Advisory Council Members

  • Develop legal risk management frameworks- a framework for assessing and classifying risks by severity and a standard response framework. Priority 5/5

3.4 Agile development for DAO toolkit

Ecosystem Actors developing the DAO toolkit or parts thereof should embrace agile development practices to ensure they do not pursue dead-ends. Regular “Show&Tell” meetings that allow the MakerDAO or subDAO communities to provide feedback can help teams to align for the most productive outcomes.

Similar principles and practices have been adopted by the software development industry at large with great success, and should be employed here.

10.4.1 Global Advocacy Initiatives

MakerDAO recognizes the importance of a harmonized regulatory approach across different countries. To this end MakerDAO will support and collaborate with advocacy groups, think tanks, and organizations globally that share its vision of promoting sensible crypto regulations.

10.4.2 Support for Advocacy Groups

To further the mission of global crypto advocacy a portion of the Support Scope budget will be allocated to support advocacy groups worldwide that align with Maker’s values and objectives.

10.4.2.1 The selection of advocacy groups will be based on criteria such as their track record, geographical reach, alignment with the Atlas ethos, and potential impact on the global crypto regulatory landscape.

10.4.2.2 Regular reports and updates from supported advocacy groups will be sought to ensure transparency, alignment, and effective utilization of resources.

10.4.3 International Collaboration and Partnerships

Recognizing the borderless nature of crypto, MakerDAO will actively seek partnerships with international bodies, organizations, and consortiums to foster a collaborative approach to crypto advocacy. Efforts will be made to share knowledge, resources, and best practices with other DAOs and crypto organizations worldwide to present a united front in advocacy efforts.

10.4.4 Continuous Monitoring and Feedback

Given the dynamic nature of global crypto regulations a dedicated team or committee within MakerDAO will continuously monitor regulatory developments worldwide. Feedback loops will be established with the Maker community and supported advocacy groups to ensure that the advocacy efforts remain relevant and effective.

10.4.5 Advocacy and Public Policy Related Budgets

The Support Facilitators have two budgets available to support the advocacy and public policy tasks described in this section: the advocacy overhead budget and the advocacy projects budget.

10.4.5.1 Advocacy Overhead Budget

Advisory Work for Protocol Advisory Council Members

Since network effects are crucial for the adoption of a stablecoin, we believe it’s essential to prioritize a comprehensive multichain strategy that includes all major L1 and L2 networks, while always maintaining a strong focus on security. This will ensure that DAI/NST is readily available and usable across the main protocols of each network, without compromising safety.

We have seen the compounding effects firsthand with USDC and their approach to aggressively supporting nascent chains.

11: Governance Security Engineering Work

Governance Security Engineering work encompasses the development, verification, deployment, and maintenance of spells and other critical components to ensure the secure operation of the Maker governance system.

11.0.1: Writing Governance Security Rulesets (new)

The creation of rulesets involves establishing the governance security parameters and standards that all spells and updates must adhere to. These rulesets must be publicly accessible and regularly updated to reflect evolving security best practices.

11.0.2: Developing Other Related Material (new)

This includes the creation of any additional documentation, tools, or resources necessary to support the governance security engineering work, such as user guides, best practices documents, and diagnostic tools.

11.1.1: Budget Implementation and Allocation

The budget is designed to be flexible and adaptable, allowing for adjustments in response to changing needs and conditions of the governance system.

11.1.2: Budget Oversight and Accountability (New)

We propose these additional qualifications:

  1. Key Account Management and/or Business Development expertise, ideally in scaling teams in Web3 or other high-growth technology areas.

  2. Experience in Creative Strategy and Development: Demonstrated experience in creative strategy and development, particularly in the context of brand building and marketing campaigns. Learnings from the AVC experiment

  • Onboarding procedure had too much friction (Buying 1 MKR, signing Etherscan messages, finding the right place on the forum, syncing with enough other AVC members)
    • The ideal process would allow a potential contributor to gain a reputation of sorts by completing smaller quests that still provide value permissionlessly and over time expanding their capacities in that way
  • No clear route to an impact
    • Without scope advisors and with no direct feedback process the position documents and scope proposals were produced without knowing if their could be a direct impact or not.
    • Giving contributors a clear path of how to make an impact makes the positions more attractive, and more valuable
  • Producing specific, aligned language was hard and required a lot of prior knowledge or intense study
    • Onboarding materials and learning journeys could bring potential contributors up to speed in a more accessible way and improve the time needed until they can give back in turn.

These hurdles would have to be removed or reduced to unlock the potential of an active community, if desired.

AVCs managed to attract a decent number of contributors despite these hurdles, showing that incentives work. Matching incentives to value produced and reducing the barriers to contributing would mean that the “ROI” could be radically improved.

Potential Advisory work- Either provide a first pass at a rigorous EGF design that meets all of the standards set in the Atlas and the spirit of the Atlas, or audit a rigorous design that the Accessibility Scope facilitators have come up with. This design would include enforcement details, such as penalties for non-compliance. This work would also need to include some level of protection against unaffiliated third parties spinning up their own frontends that do not meet EGF requirements- perhaps by incentivizing EGF standards, or perhaps by somehow incorporating wallet signatures that reveal which frontend the lockstake engine was accessed by. Priority 2/5

  • Refine the guidelines that must be followed for Ecosystem Actors to receive the accessibility reward, ensuring it effectively grows the NewStablecoin brand. This work can only be prioritized after the rebrand and after initial accessibility reward parameters are set. Priority may increase at this point. Priority 1/5

  • Optimize MakerDAO’s presence on external platforms, developing frameworks for communications on external platforms and identifying the most effective channels for reaching and engaging with the target audience. Priority 1/5

  • Define and update best practices for SubDAO frontend standards in terms of security, user experience, and required features. Priority 4/5

  • Research and develop a framework for long term Accessibility Campaigns. Priority 1/5

  • Refine the guidelines for the Accessibility chat, ensuring it remains a welcoming and informative space for newcomers and experienced users alike while maintaining a clear distinction from governance-focused discussions. Priority 1/5

Section MIP 113 (Governance Scope)

  • As the Scope contains the following text: “The Governance Facilitators must put in place processes to monitor the Ecosystem Actors for risks of conflict of interest between Advisory Council Members and Active Ecosystem Actors, and ensure that the Scope Artifacts and the checks they place on Active Ecosystem Actors are in Universal Alignment with the Atlas.” , such processes need to be designed. These processes should somehow also receive broad acceptance from the community. Priority 3/5
  • Audit of the powers given to and checks on each type of Alignment Conserver to ensure power is balanced. Priority 2/5 but may increase as we near the launch of FacilitatorDAOs. These powers and constraints should be clearly visible in a an easily accessible place.

item.dc:creator: JanSky
item.description:
Scenario Summary:

An Aligned Delegate (AD) added communications in April for votes that took place in February, aiming to increase their communication score and compensation. The Governance Facilitators observed this delayed update and determined that it did not meet the Atlas’ “actively communicating” standard due to the 6-week delay. The AD argued that the Atlas does not specify a strict time requirement for submitting vote communications and requested the decision be reconsidered.

Interpretation and Outcome:

According to the Atlas, Aligned Delegates (ADs) must meet specific participation and communication requirements to qualify for compensation. These requirements are outlined in sections 2.6.3.6 and 2.6.3.8, which emphasize timely and active participation and communication.

Key Clauses from the Atlas:

2.6.3.6:
ADs must participate in AVC Subcommittee Meetings to qualify for full income. Participation must be meaningful and contribute useful research and information, which implies that the timeliness and relevance of participation are critical.

2.6.3.7:
Voting activity metrics modify AD income payouts, requiring a high level of consistent voting activity over the past 6 months.

2.6.3.8:
Communication metrics for the last 12 months are also crucial. ADs must actively communicate their voting rationale to maintain transparency and assist MKR holders in understanding governance decisions. Specifically, if an AD actively communicates on less than 95% of votes over the last 6 months, their income is reduced.

Interpretation:

The term “actively communicating” in the context of the Atlas implies that ADs must provide timely and relevant communication about their voting activities. This requirement ensures transparency and allows MKR holders to understand the rationale behind votes in a timely manner. While the Atlas does not specify an exact timeframe for submitting communications, it is implicit that these should be done within a reasonable period after the vote to be considered “active.”

Based on the facts provided, adding communications for February votes in April does not meet the standard of “actively communicating.” A 6-week delay undermines the purpose of timely and transparent governance. Thus, such retroactive edits should not count toward future compensation calculations.

Reasonable Timeframe for Communication:

To clarify the expectations and prevent similar disputes, we suggest implementing a specific timeframe for submitting vote communications. A period of one week after the conclusion of a vote is reasonable for ADs to provide their explanations and align with the Atlas’ intent of active participation. This timeframe ensures that communications are timely, relevant, and useful for governance purposes.

Discretion for Extenuating Circumstances:

While the one-week rule provides clear guidance, some discretion should be granted to Governance Facilitators to account for extenuating circumstances. For instance, delays caused by technical issues, calendar irregularities, or other significant impediments could warrant exceptions. Facilitators should evaluate such cases individually to determine if a delay is justified.

Conclusion:

Editing or adding communications after a compensation period has ended should not count toward future compensation calculations. To maintain the integrity of the governance process, ADs must adhere to a one-week timeframe for submitting vote communications. Governance Facilitators should exercise discretion in exceptional cases but uphold the principle of timely and active communication as per the Atlas’ standards.

Addendum: Processing Expired Contracts and Carryover Period

Context:

There was an additional question when calculating compensation regarding how to handle expired delegate contracts and the MKR voting weight associated with them. Delegate contracts expire after one year, and sometimes MKR holders (delegators) do not immediately move their MKR to a new contract. This addendum provides guidance on how to process these expired contracts while maintaining compliance with the Atlas.

Conclusion:

To ensure a smooth transition and prevent unnecessary disruptions in governance participation, we will allow for a two-week carryover period when a delegate contract expires. During this period, the voting weight from expired contracts will continue to count towards a delegate’s vote weight for compensation calculations. This approach balances the need for continuity with adherence to the Atlas’ requirements.

Justification:

2.6.3: Aligned Delegate Income and Participation Requirements
  • ADs are eligible to receive income based on their voting weight and participation. This eligibility is critical for maintaining active and aligned governance participation.
  • Ensuring a short carryover period helps maintain the integrity of compensation calculations while accommodating the practicalities of transitioning MKR voting weight.
  • Delegates with active delegators, who can respond within a short period of change, should not be punished based on the arbitrary expiration of contracts. Two weeks provides ample time for delegates to broadcast their new contracts while not substantially risky security assumptions of delegation.

item.title: Constructive community engagement
item.dc:creator: Shiko
item.description:
Constructive community engagement


In Maker, community members navigate a complex environment that offers both benefits and challenges. The benefits include anonymity and broad community engagement, while the challenges involve managing anonymous interactions and ensuring positive community behavior. By applying insights from urban sociology, we may be able to develop effective strategies to address these challenges.

The urban framework

The essence of urban life, with its blend of anonymity and community, provides a valuable framework for understanding interactions within DAOs. Anonymity in digital spaces, akin to the walking down the street of a city, offers individuals the freedom to express themselves without the constraints of their offline identities. However, this anonymity can also lead to challenges, particularly when it concerns accountability and behavior in online communities.

Anonymity as freedom and challenge

The city’s anonymity offers a sense of freedom, allowing individuals to interact without the constraints of their real-world identities. This can encourage open expression and innovation. However, as Danah Boyd, a researcher specializing in online community dynamics, points out, this same anonymity can also disrupt social dynamics. It can enable individuals to act in ways they might avoid if their true identities were known, leading to behavior that can be harmful or disruptive. Boyd notes that while removing anonymity might seem like a solution to these issues, such challenges are complex and are not likely to be resolved simply by exposing real identities, reflecting the nuanced impact of anonymity in digital spaces.

Implementing urban social codes in DAOs

Urban sociology introduces the concept of “civil inattention,” which Irving Goffman describes as a social behavior that allows individuals to coexist peacefully in crowded environments by acknowledging each other’s presence respectfully without intruding into personal space. This concept can be invaluable in digital communities, where respectful engagement needs to be balanced with privacy and personal boundaries.

Civil inattention in digital spaces

In DAOs, implementing a digital form of civil inattention could involve community guidelines built into the Atlas that promote respectful acknowledgment without unnecessary intrusion—encouraging members to interact within the bounds of digital etiquette. This approach could help in managing interactions that might otherwise escalate into conflicts due to misinterpretation or the perceived anonymity shield.

Community engagement and governance: establishing norms in the Atlas

One of the primary concerns within DAOs revolves around determining which behaviors are considered harmful enough to warrant moderation or even a ban, like - deliberate malicious behavior. This requires a nuanced understanding of the community’s values and the specific context of each interaction.

Establishing behavioral norms

Community engagement must focus on delineating clear guidelines that define acceptable and unacceptable behaviors. These norms should not only discourage detrimental activities but also promote a positive, constructive dialogue that enhances the community’s overall fabric.

Powerhouse / @wouter is hopefully considering this as they are figuring out the reputation system, while Atlas Axis / @Le_Bateleur is dealing with the Atlas integration.

To other community members reading along, lets start mapping malicious behaviour.

Encouraging positive engagement

In our community, the anonymity that provides freedom can also, regrettably, be manipulated for less constructive purposes. Some people may use this veil of secrecy to create multiple accounts or amplify their own views in ways that do not reflect the true consensus of the community. Such actions not only skew honest dialogue but also threaten the integrity and trust.

It’s important to recognize that while it is easier to critique and disrupt than to build and support, the lasting impact of our community depends on each of us choosing the harder right over the easier wrong. I urge all community members to embrace the responsibility that comes with anonymity — using it not as a shield for malice, but as a space for honest, respectful discourse.

Let’s strive to ensure our interactions are guided by the principle of building up rather than tearing down.

Summary

Phoenix Labs proposes the following changes to SparkLend grouped by individual polls:

  1. [Mainnet+Gnosis] Turn off silo borrowing for all stablecoins
  2. [Mainnet+Gnosis] IRM Refresh
  3. [Mainnet] Update Morpho Vault Supply Caps
  4. [Gnosis] Disable Governance Bridge Security Delay

Rational

[Mainnet+Gnosis] Turn off silo borrowing for all stablecoins

Silo borrowing is a bad user experience, and after discussion with the risk team it is not deemed to be necessary for stablecoins pegged to the underlying asset price.

Block Analitica will comment further on the risks.

[Mainnet+Gnosis] IRM Refresh

Various markets on Mainnet and Gnosis need IRM refreshes. This includes both stablecoin and ETH markets.

Block Analitica will provide all the parameters.

[Mainnet] Update Morpho Vault Supply Caps

Supply caps limit the facilitators ability to mint more DAI into the market. The sUSDe 91.5% vault has reached it’s cap of 50m which can be extended.

Block Analitica will comment further on the risks.

[Gnosis] Turn off bridge security delay

Spark governance on Gnosis is under a 2 day delay in addition to the mainnet Maker Pause Proxy security delay. This is used to protect against bridge risk however, since Spark uses the canonical bridge for messaging there is no additional protection provided as any hack of the bridge will be able to steal all the assets as well.

It is recommended to lower this delay to 0 which also requires setting the minimum delay limit to 0 as well.
